name: Oxygen Delivery - Hypoxia
question1: Oxygen carrying capacity?  What are the causes of hypoxia?
contents:
Causes of Hypoxia (4)

  • (1) Hypoxic
  • (2) Anaemic
  • (3) Stagnant
  • (4) Histotoxic


If we plot the differences on Oxygen partial pressure (kPa) vs %Saturation graphs

  • In hypoxic hypoxia -
  • both the partial pressure of O2 for arterial and venous will go down
  • PaO2 - less partial pressure of Oxygen being delivered - arterial goes down
  • PvO2 - more oxygen extraction at the tissues - venous goes down
  • In Anaemic hypoxia
  • PaO2 - Partial pressure of Oxygen will stay the same (
  • PvO2 - Venous will go down - as reduced content (global oxygen delivery is reduced) of O2 in the blood due to less Haemaglobin to carry it - so venous will go down - more extraction
  • In Stagnant hypoxia
  • Both PaO2 and PvO2 are normal.
  • Tissues and organs do not receive the oxygenated blood due to perfusion failure.
  • In Histotoxic hypoxia
  • PaO2 is normal
  • PvO2 is increased - as unable to utilise the oxygen
question2: Discuss and calculate the Oxygen content of normal and (4) different hypoxias.
contents2:
In a normal person breathing air : 

  • Bound to Hb - arterial blood contains about 20ml O2 per 100ml blood / venous 15ml per 100ml
  • Dissolved - arterial blood 0.3ml per 100ml / venous 0.1ml per 100mls 


What is the Oxygen content : In a normal person breathing air : 

  • Oxygen content = [Bound O2] + [Dissolved O2
  • Oxygen carrying capacity = (1.34 x Hb x sats) + (0.003 x PO2) - of the blood per 100ml/decilitre.


Solubility factor for carbon dioxide in plasma is 0.003mmol/100ml/mmHg (eg PaO2 x solubility factor)


Oxygen content = [Hb x 1.34 x SaO2] + [PaO2 x 0.00225]  (SaO2 = arterial O2 saturation as %) 

  • Arterial O2 content = [15 x 1.34 x 1.0] + [13.3kPa x 0.00225] = [20.1] + [0.3] = 20.4ml of oxygen per dL
  • Venous O2 content = [Hb x 1.34 x 0.75] + [5.3kPa x 0.00225] = 15ml of oxygen per dl.


4 Different types of Hypoxia

Hypoxic hypoxia - Low Fi02, Hypoventilation, Diffusion impairment, VQ mismatch. Shunt 

  • AO2 content = [15 x 1.34 x 0.85] + [6.5 x 0.00225] = 17ml O2/dl
  • VO2 content = [15 x 1.34 x 0.45] + [3.0 x 0.00225] = 9ml O2/dl


Anaemia hypoxia (PaO2 normal, PvO2 low) low O2 carrying capacity → Increased Oxygen extraction and venous desaturation.

  • AO2 content = [7 x 1.34 x 1.0] + [13.3 x 0.00225] = 10ml O2/dl
  • VO2 content = [7 x 1.34 x 0.5] + [4.0 x 0.00225] = 5ml O2/dl

**(Anaemia only affects oxygen carrying capacity, not PO2)


Stagnant hypoxia - eg Cardiogenic shock (same as normal circulatory dysfunction results inadequate O2 delivery to organs and venous sats may even be increased.)

PaO2 normal, PvO2 normal. 

  • AO2 content = [15 x 1.34 x 1.0] + [13.3kPa x 0.00225] = 20.4ml/dl = 204ml/L
  • VO2 content= [Hb x 1.34 x 0.75] + [5.3kPa x 0.00225] = 15ml/dl = 150ml/L


Histotoxic hypoxia - eg cyanide poisoning. (PaO2 normal, PvO2 high) cells unable to utilise O2 resulting in high venous saturations. 

  • AO2 content = [15 x 1.34 x 1.0] + [13.3 x 0.00225] = 20ml O2/dl = 200ml/L
  • VO2 content = [15 x 1.34 x 0.9] + [8.0 x 0.00225] = 18ml O2/dl = 180ml/L


(see Fick’s law below - 20ml O2/dl = 200 ml/L)


Arterial blood contains 20ml of oxygen per 100ml blood (i.e. 200ml per litre)

19.7ml combined to Hb

0.3ml dissolved in plasma

Venous blood contains approximately 15ml of oxygen per 100ml blood (i.e. 150ml per litre)
question3: What methods can be used to increase Oxygen content and delivery? What is oxygen flux? What is normal VO2?
contents3:
Increase CaO2 and or increasing CO

To increase CaO2 : increase circulating Hb, maintain higher O2 saturations, increase dissolved oxygen by increasing the partial pressure of oxygen (eg hyperbaric O2)

To increase CO: optimise HR and rhythm (60-90 bpm/sinus), optimise stroke volume (eg preload and contractility) , maintain perfusion pressure to ensure oxygen delivery (ie, afterload), the above can be achieved with fluids and or inotropes.


Oxygen flux = amount of oxygen delivered to the tissues (not taken up) per unit time, and equals the cardiac output multiplied by the arterial oxygen content


  • 5L/min x 200ml/L (arterial blood contains 200ml/L of O2) = 1000ml/min
  • Normally 850 - 1200 ml /minute

The delivery of any substance to an organ can be calculated if the concentration of the substance and the flow rate are measured.

DCO2 = CO x CaO2 (x10) (multiplier of 10 because CaO2 is measured in ml.dl-1 whereas CO is measured in L.min-1)


Normal VO2 = 3.5ml/kg/min = 250ml/min


  • Thyrotoxicosis = 3.86ml/kg/min
  • Dobutamine in healthy males (+15%) = 4ml/kg/min
  • Sepsis syndrome (+30%) = 4.55ml/kg/min
  • Term pregnancy (+40%) = 5ml/kg/min
  • Neonates = 7ml/kg/min 

Therefore normal extraction ratio = 0.25


MET = metabolic equivalents : 1 MET = 3.5ml of O2/kg/min
question4: Oxygen stores.  Why is the O2 Dissociation curve a sigmoid shape (2)
contents4:
O2 stores and transport 

Total body oxygen stores : are about 1.5L : 50% carried by Hb : 30% in lungs : 20% in myoglobin 


Oxygen is carried in two forms in the blood 

  • Dissolved in plasma 
  • Bound to Haemoglobin - in RBC’s 

Hb contains two alpha and two beta polypeptide chains each of which contain a haem group (a porphyrin ring with an Fe2+ atom that can reversibly bind one molecule of O2) 

Cooperativity - The binding of one molecule of O2 increases the affinity of the other haem groups for O2. 

Allosteric modulation - when O2 binds to Hb the two beta chains move closer together. (R state) 


The O2 Dissociation curve (OHDC) - Sigmoid due to allosteric binding and cooperativity. 


  • Describes the % Oxygen occupancy of Haemoglobin Hb and other carried molecules at different partial pressures of Oxygen (P02)
  • The upper part of the curve is flat, which means that Hb is 90% saturated even when arterial P02 decreases. (there is reserve in the system) 
  • Bohr effect describes the shift in position of the OHDC in relation to the amount of CO2 within the blood.
  • OHDC shifts to right - **more** more H+ ions, more temp, more 2,3 DPG, more PaCO2. Etc.
